utterances: Can you explain for people who may not understand, why did they have to move some of the houses?
Because they were close to the river.
And if you're going to build a flood protection project to protect a city - a dike - then those homes have to go on until the infrastructure is solid.
Can you just give us a little example of some of the other things that were done to mitigate flood damage?
Well, you have one-stop shops where you have - when a person comes for a building permit or something, you have everything available for them in one office.
So they don't have to go from city hall to public works to somewhere else.
So that one-stop shop really facilitated recovery.
Meaning people would go to this one office, would be able to get all the permits they needed?
Right, all the permits and permission.
And it's also absolutely essential that there are solid partnerships between all agencies in the government, the county, the city, public works and the school district.
Everybody has to be on the same page moving forward.
City planners in Houston are going to have to make some tough choices.
What advice do you have for them?
Make them (laughter).
And don't do what's popular.
Do what's right.
You have to protect the community, its future.
Or it won't be able to grow up.
It won't be able to attract industry or business.
You need to have a safe, vibrant, prospering, growing community to do well.
Michael Brown, mayor of Grand Forks, N.D.
Thank you very much.
Thank you.
My pleasure.

Now there's a transitional government with international backing but little authority.
In General Aideed's day, he had a lock on the presidential palace.
That's because he had the key to the front door.
Before the general was mortally wounded in a street fight with another warlord in 1996, he controlled the presidential palace and about half of Somalia.
Hussein does not.
To hear Somalis tell it, the son squandered the father's trust.
(Through translator) In Somalia, there is legend, which says that the lion delivered a cat.
So that Mohamed delivered already a cat.
(Laughing)
That's Sheik Mohamed Ali.
He's an elder of the minority Asharaf clan.

The Sheik said he respected the general as a man of his words, but with regards to the son, the Sheik is willing to say aloud what many Somalis only whisper that Hussein may not be clever enough or tough enough to fill his old man's boots.
(Through translator) The difference between Hussein Aideed and his father was his father was a dictator.
He was seen tough.
Do what I say, nothing else.
Who was not taken (unintelligible) who are like employees.
But Hussein, (unintelligible) people.
He takes our side.
But his father was very (unintelligible).
Adi Rasak(ph) is unemployed in Mogadishu with 10 children and a wife to feed.
He sees the son as a new and improved Aideed.
(Through translator) Hussein Aideed is one of the leaders that we prefer to become president of Somalia because he respected the (unintelligible) of the people.
He is young, and I wish he's better than his father.
Hussein has another arrow in his quiver, another little something that sets him apart from the others here.
He's got a kind of American optimism about his ability to shape the future of Somalia.
That's probably because he is an American and a Republican and an ex-U.S.
Marine, and the way he tells it, a patriot.
Remember when Hussein was 16 and his family packed him up for California?
Well, after graduating from Covina High School, Hussein joined the Marines and became a U.S.
citizen.
I had to kill that desire inside me to do something for the nation.
All the education, all the good, not only me, to my family they have given said you have to serve, like my father served Somali.
Hussein Aideed served in Iraq during the first Gulf War and in 1992, his Marine division deployed for a then starving Somalia.
It was a humanitarian relief mission called Operation Restore Hope.
Aideed's job was to help keep the warlords at bay so that the food could actually get to the hungry and not to their peckish militias.
As a U.S.
Marine, Hussein was more than ready for duty.
But as a Somali, he flinched.
It's the deception of the aspirations which I grew up, the dream, it's completely gone, and I saw the children like myself.
So I felt very bad.
I felt here something evil happen.
In 1993, the situation got worse.
That's when Aideed, as a Marine reserve, faced up to the biggest warlord in Somalia.
It was the man the U.S.
had tried to foil by bombing and capturing his lieutenants.
It was the man whose militia had shot down two Black Hawk helicopters in Mogadishu.
The Americans needed this man to give up his hostage, a downed U.S.
Army pilot named Michael Durant.
So Hussein Aideed says he sat down and wrote a letter.
The letter I sent were a greeting to my dad.
The family's good.
We are in good condition.
There is no threat with our life in the U.S.
We are - there is no problems.
So I explained to him and I said you need to release the pilot of the helicopter.
Whether or not Hussein's letter made a difference, Durant was released.

Now, sitting in his comfortable home just minutes away from Somalia's presidential palace, Hussein Aideed says he's waiting for the right time to meet Durant and perhaps close that chapter of their lives.
I have this dog tag.
Every Marine has - I have my dog tag.
I want to give when I see him, Michael Durant.
I have his dog tag.
I have his rifle here, the rifle he was using.
I will give it to him.
To hear Aideed tell it, it's the least a Marine, an American, a Somali, a man who would be president can do.
Gwen Thompkins, NPR News, Mogadishu.
It's not often that there's a new majority sworn in on both sides of the Capitol, in both chambers.
And in recent times, turnovers happened less often in the House than in the Senate.
In January 1955, the Democrats assumed control of the House and they held on to it for 40 years.
It took the GOP until January 1995 to take it back.
Please, all of you raise your right hand.
Do you solemnly swear that you will support the…
Here's one measure of how long 40 years is.
When the new speaker, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, addressed the 104th Congress 12 years ago today, not a single member of his caucus had served long enough to have ever been a member of the majority.

So much history had transpired while the GOP walked the political wilderness that when he spoke that day, Gingrich acknowledged some of what the Democrats had gotten right in their age of ascendancy from the New Deal through the civil rights movement.
The fact is, it was the liberal wing of the Democratic Party that ended segregation.
The fact is it was Franklin Delano Roosevelt who gave hope to a nation that was in despair and could have slid into dictatorship.
And the fact is every Republican has much to learn from studying what the Democrats did right.
But I would say to my friends…
Now, he said, the Republicans had something to teach the Democrats.
In 1995, we followed some House freshmen.
One of them was Republican J.C.
Watts of Okalahoma, who reminisced with us a couple of weeks ago.
Mr.
J.C.
WATTS (Former Republican Representative for Okalahoma): There's an energy, excitement - I think a little bit of naivete'.
I think whether you were in the majority or the minority, there was an excitement, an energy.
You're comeing to make a difference, have an impact and setting the course of the nation.
And we had a hand in that.
California Democrat Zoe Lofgren also came to Capitol Hill in 1995.
She had run hoping - even expecting - to be in yet another Democratic majority.
Instead, she took her seat in the minority.
She gives the Republicans credit for one thing: they reduced the power of committee chairmen who, in the past, had run their committees like personal fiefdoms.
If you were wondering why the financial crisis and the recent rioting in Greece matters to you, well, the answer came on Thursday.
Nina Totenberg, NPR News, Washington.
There are roughly 120,000 American troops in Afghanistan and Iraq.
And on Thanksgiving, those two places may in fact be easiest in the world to locate pumpkin pie, stuffing and cranberry sauce.

That's because the Defense Logistics Agency, which is an office of the Pentagon, has been busy for months making sure that tens of thousands of pounds of turkey, bread rolls and all the Thanksgiving trimmings will arrive to those troops in time.
Rich Faso is the man in charge of this endeavor and here's his Thanksgiving shopping list just for Afghanistan.
Thirty thousand pounds of turkey breast, 38,000 pounds of whole turkey, 18,000 pounds of smoked whole turkey, 30,000 pounds of ham, 27,000 pies, as well as 13,000 pounds of cranberry sauce.
Rich, how do you begin to plan all that?
When does this process actually start?
Well, Guy, when most people are planning their vacations for the summer, we're busy thinking about Thanksgiving.
So, in the May timeframe, roughly six months prior to the event.
So how many people are actually involved in making this happen?
I mean, you say you started doing this over the summer.
There must be hundreds of people trying to figure out how to get Thanksgiving dinners to troops in sometimes very remote parts of Afghanistan and Iraq.
